abstract.text: An object that describes an item in a tab bar.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: A tab bar item is a segment of a tab bar that represents a specific section of your app. A tab bar displays one or more items that allow the user to switch between the different sections. The user can select one item at a time.
The most common approach for displaying a tab bar is to use a tab bar controller. The controller’s tab bar displays an item for each view controller you provide when you set the
method. You’re responsible for supplying the tab bar items. Do this by setting each view controller’s
property. When the user selects an item, the tab bar controller displays its view controller. For more information, see
You can also use a tab bar independent of a tab bar controller. After creating a tab bar, add it to your view hierarchy. Provide the items by setting the tab bar’s
method. In this configuration, you’re responsible for updating the view hierarchy to display the correct content. Use
to know when the selection changes. For more information, see

The system provides several tab bar items for common use cases. If you need a custom item, create one with a title and an image. You can further customize the item by providing an alternate image that appears when the user selects it. By default, the item doesn’t display the images you provide. Instead, it generates new images from the alpha values of your images and tints them. To prevent this, provide images that use the

An item can adjust its appearance when in certain conditions. For example, you can specify different appearances for inline and compact inline layouts or for when the item’s state changes. To do this, set the item’s
property. If you don’t want this behavior, you can set the individual properties on the item instead.

A tab bar item can display a supplementary value in a badge that provides extra information to the user. For example, the Phone app uses a badge’s value to display the number of missed calls. You can customize the badge’s appearance, including its background color and text attributes.

abstract.text: Construct and manage a graphical, event-driven user interface for your iOS, iPadOS, or tvOS app.
Methods that associate a unique identifier with elements in your user interface.
A collection of methods that gives you access to the appearance proxy for a class.
An abstract superclass for items that you can add to a bar that appears at the bottom of the screen.
Always draw the original image, without treating it as a template.
Navigational controls that display in a bar along the top of the screen, usually in conjunction with a navigation controller.
A container view controller that defines a stack-based scheme for navigating hierarchical content.
The items that a navigation bar displays when the associated view controller is visible.
A container view controller that manages navigation between pages of content, where a subview controller manages each page.
A type that can be an anchor for a popover presentation controller.
A tab subclass that represents the system’s search tab.
A container view controller that implements a hierarchical interface.
The interface that determines if an object supports a spring-loaded interaction for drag and drop activities.
An object that manages a tab in a tab bar.
A control that displays one or more buttons in a tab bar for selecting between different subtasks, views, or modes in an app.
The items displayed by the tab bar.
Sets the items on the tab bar, optionally animating any changes into position.
A container view controller that manages a multiselection interface, where the selection determines which child view controller to display.
Sets the root view controllers of the tab bar controller.
An array of the root view controllers displayed by the tab bar interface.
The
protocol defines optional methods for a delegate of a
object. The

class provides the ability for the user to reorder, remove, and add items to the tab bar; this process is referred to as customizing the tab bar. The tab bar delegate receives messages when customizing occurs.
An object that describes an item in a tab bar.
Constants that represent the system tab bar items.
The background color of the item’s badge.
Returns the badge’s text attributes for the specified state.
The text that the item’s badge displays.
Returns the finished selected image.
Returns the finished unselected image.
Creates a tab bar item with a default configuration.
Creates a tab bar item from a serialized instance.
Creates a tab bar item using a system-provided configuration.
Creates a tab bar item that toggles the image it displays when its selected state changes.
Creates a tab bar item that displays a title and an image.
The appearance settings for the tab bar when the edge of scrollable content aligns with the edge of the tab bar.
The source image the item uses to generate its selected image.
Registers text attributes that the badge uses for the specified state.
Sets the finished selected and unselected images.
The appearance settings for a tab bar.
The offset to apply to the title’s position.
An object that manages a collection of tab objects.
The tab bar item that represents the view controller when added to a tab bar controller.
Create a composite interface by combining content from one or more view controllers with other custom views.

abstract.text: A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A type whose values can be implicitly or explicitly copied.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
